data.title: Private Papers of Group Captain J E Pelly-Fry DSO
data.meta_description: Informative ts memoir (575pp) describing his RAF career, June 1933 - September 1958, including: training with the RAF at the de Havilland School of Flying, Hatfield, Surrey, June 1933 - October 1934; short service RAF Commission, April 1935; No 3 FTS, RAF Spitalgate (Grantham, Lincolnshire), April - June 1935; attached to No 7 and No 58 (Bomber) Squadrons, RAF Worthy Down, Hampshire, September - O
data.text:
This media is not currently available online. Contact the Image and Film Licensing team about access

Description

Object description

Informative ts memoir (575pp) describing his RAF career, June 1933 - September 1958, including: training with the RAF at the de Havilland School of Flying, Hatfield, Surrey, June 1933 - October 1934; short service RAF Commission, April 1935; No 3 FTS, RAF Spitalgate (Grantham, Lincolnshire), April - June 1935; attached to No 7 and No 58 (Bomber) Squadrons, RAF Worthy Down, Hampshire, September - October 1935; No 216 (Bomber Transport) Squadron, Heliopolis, Egypt, November 1935 - October 1938 (Nairobi, Kenya, October 1936 - January 1937); Personal Assistant to AOC Palestine and Trans-Jordan, Jerusalem (later Marshal of the RAF Sir Arthur Harris), October 1938 - July 1939; Flight Commander, No 223 (Bomber) Squadron RAF, Kenya and Sudan, July 1939 - August 1940; CO No 47 Squadron RAF, Sudan and Ethiopia, August 1940 - January 1941; Intelligence Officer, HQ Middle East, Cairo, February 1941 - January 1942; staff officer, HQ No 92 Group (Bomber Command), RAF Winslow, Bucks, February - May 1942; No 17 OTU, RAF Upwood, Cambridgeshire, May - June 1942; CO No 88 Squadron (No 2 Group, Bomber Command), RAF Attlebridge and RAF Oulton (near Norwich, Norfolk), and RAF Hartford Bridge, Hampshire (near Camberley), No 2 Group, Bomber Command, June 1942 - October 1943 (DSO for raid on Eindhoven flying the Boston, December 1942); Extra Air Equerry to King George VI, Buckingham Palace, October 1943 - January 1944; Station Commander, RAF Holme-on Spalding Moor (No 4 Group, Bomber Command), Yorkshire, April 1944 - August 1945; Station Commander (Transport Command), RAF Camden (near Sydney), New South Wales, October 1945 - February 1946; civilian life as a commercial pilot and gaining a permanent commission in the RAF, February 1946 - January 1949; Wing Commander i/c Admin, RAF Syerston (near Newark, Nottinghamshire), January 1949 - January 1950; Deputy President, RAF Selection Board, Ramridge House (near Andover, Hampshire), January 1950 - June 1952; attending NATO Defence College, Paris, June - December 1952; posted to Plans, Policy & Operations Division, SHAPE, Paris, January 1953 - January 1955; converting to Meteor jets, 12 FTS, RAF Weston Zoyland, Somerset, April - May 1955; Air Attaché, Teheran, Iran, July 1955 - September 1958, when he retired; Civil Air Adviser, British High Commissioners in Australia and New Zealand, Melbourne, 1959 - late 1962; commercial sales representative, Handley Page Ltd, March 1963 - 1966; and commenting on RAF life, his duties, and many personalities, notably Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia; the Shah of Iran; Marshals of the RAF Lords Portal and Tedder; Air Chief Marshal Sir Basil Embury; Air Marshal Sir George Beamish; Air Vice Marshal R Collishaw VC; Squadron Leader M T St J Pattle; Field Marshal Lord Montgomery; General Sir William Platt; Major Generals D L Lloyd-Owen and O C Wingate; and C G Grey. Also included are six pilot's licences, October 1933 - May 1947; three pilot's flying log books, June 1933 - August 1961; a Member's Card (1p), RAF Flying Club, March 1936; an Official Pass (4pp) issued by HQ RAF Palestine and Trans-Jordan, May 1939; five photographs of No 88 Squadron RAF; a pamphlet (14pp) for No 47 Squadron RAF Diamond Jubilee, 1916 - 1976; two undated letters (2pp) of Safe Conduct addressed to Arabs and Ethiopians; undated ts account (11pp) describing his discovery of the first jerrican in Iraq, May 1941; ts precis (6pp) of his career, 1933 - 1966; a Certificate (2pp) of Instrument Pilot Rating (RAF Form 5214A), issued February 1952.

Content description

Informative ts memoir (575pp) describing his RAF career, June 1933 - September 1958, including: training with the RAF at the de Havilland School of Flying, Hatfield, Surrey, June 1933 - October 1934; short service RAF Commission, April 1935; No 3 FTS, RAF Spitalgate (Grantham, Lincolnshire), April - June 1935; attached to No 7 and No 58 (Bomber) Squadrons, RAF Worthy Down, Hampshire, September - October 1935; No 216 (Bomber Transport) Squadron, Heliopolis, Egypt, November 1935 - October 1938 (Nairobi, Kenya, October 1936 - January 1937); Personal Assistant to AOC Palestine and Trans-Jordan, Jerusalem (later Marshal of the RAF Sir Arthur Harris), October 1938 - July 1939; Flight Commander, No 223 (Bomber) Squadron RAF, Kenya and Sudan, July 1939 - August 1940; CO No 47 Squadron RAF, Sudan and Ethiopia, August 1940 - January 1941; Intelligence Officer, HQ Middle East, Cairo, February 1941 - January 1942; staff officer, HQ No 92 Group (Bomber Command), RAF Winslow, Bucks, February - May 1942; No 17 OTU, RAF Upwood, Cambridgeshire, May - June 1942; CO No 88 Squadron (No 2 Group, Bomber Command), RAF Attlebridge and RAF Oulton (near Norwich, Norfolk), and RAF Hartford Bridge, Hampshire (near Camberley), No 2 Group, Bomber Command, June 1942 - October 1943 (DSO for raid on Eindhoven flying the Boston, December 1942); Extra Air Equerry to King George VI, Buckingham Palace, October 1943 - January 1944; Station Commander, RAF Holme-on Spalding Moor (No 4 Group, Bomber Command), Yorkshire, April 1944 - August 1945; Station Commander (Transport Command), RAF Camden (near Sydney), New South Wales, October 1945 - February 1946; civilian life as a commercial pilot and gaining a permanent commission in the RAF, February 1946 - January 1949; Wing Commander i/c Admin, RAF Syerston (near Newark, Nottinghamshire), January 1949 - January 1950; Deputy President, RAF Selection Board, Ramridge House (near Andover, Hampshire), January 1950 - June 1952; attending NATO Defence College, Paris, June - December 1952; posted to Plans, Policy & Operations Division, SHAPE, Paris, January 1953 - January 1955; converting to Meteor jets, 12 FTS, RAF Weston Zoyland, Somerset, April - May 1955; Air Attaché, Teheran, Iran, July 1955 - September 1958, when he retired; Civil Air Adviser, British High Commissioners in Australia and New Zealand, Melbourne, 1959 - late 1962; Air Chief Marshal Sir Basil Embury; Air Marshal Sir George Beamish; Air Vice Marshal R Collishaw VC; Squadron Leader M T St J Pattle; Field Marshal Lord Montgomery; General Sir William Platt; Major Generals D L Lloyd-Owen and O C Wingate; and C G Grey. Also included are six pilot's licences, October 1933 - May 1947; three pilot's flying log books, June 1933 - August 1961; a Member's Card (1p), RAF Flying Club, March 1936; an Official Pass (4pp) issued by HQ RAF Palestine and Trans-Jordan, May 1939; five photographs of No 88 Squadron RAF; a pamphlet (14pp) for No 47 Squadron RAF Diamond Jubilee, 1916 - 1976; two undated letters (2pp) of Safe Conduct addressed to Arabs and Ethiopians; undated ts account (11pp) describing his discovery of the first jerrican in Iraq, May 1941; ts precis (6pp) of his career, 1933 - 1966; a Certificate (2pp) of Instrument Pilot Rating (RAF Form 5214A), issued February 1952.

History note

Cataloguer SNR

History note

Catalogue date 1995-11-26

Our collections information

We have over a million object records online, and we are adding to this all the time. Our records are never finished. Sometimes we discover new information that changes what we know about an object, such as who made it or used it. Sometimes we change how an object is interpreted. We sometimes make mistakes in our spelling, transcription or categorisation, or miss information out of our records.

Read more about our collections and the information we hold. Developing our collections information

If you have concerns about the language in this record, or you have information to improve it, please share your feedback.

Our collections information

Please use this form to give us feedback on an object. The form will be sent to our Collections Management Team who will use it to improve our object records. We receive a lot of comments and can't respond to each one, but we do read them all and will respond where we can.

Read more about our collections and the information we hold.

Contemporary conflict

Timeline of 20th and 21st Century Wars

Military conflict took place during every year of the 20th Century. There were only short periods of time that the world was free of war. The total number of deaths caused by war during the 20th Century has been estimated at 187 million and is probably higher. Explore the timeline of 20th and 21st century wars using IWM's extensive online collection.

© IWM (MH 11040)

Second World War

How Europe Went To War In 1939

The Second World War was the most destructive conflict in human history. Years of international tension and aggressive expansion by Fascist Italy and Nazi Germany culminated in the German invasion of Poland on 1 September 1939. Britain and France declared war on Germany two days later.
